39032505.review:
생뚱맞음이 지나치면 도리어 무덤덤해진다.

도트 감성의 게임이지만 요크샤이어 구빈즈 특유의 픽셀 그래픽은 딱히 뛰어나다고 평해주긴 좀 어려워보인다. 그래도 풀더빙이라는 점은 좀 칭찬해줘야 할지도. (성우의 연기 수준은 별개로 놓고 본다 치더라도) 인간을 흉내내는 달팽이괴물에 로봇에 온갖 뜬금없는 것들이 등장해 온갖 사고를 치는데, 오히려 뜬금없음이 너무 과해서 무덤덤해져 버린다. 비정상인들이 난무하고 유머가 가득한 어드벤처 게임치고는 이야기가 너무 정석적인 느낌이다.

본편에 해당하는 '험블 파이'와 보너스 에피소드는 그냥 고만고만하게 재밌다. 무난하지만, 강하게 추천할 정도로 재밌다고 보긴 좀 어려운 수준. 그 대신 튜토리얼격에 해당하는 '동사 학교'가 포인트 앤 클릭 게임의 클리셰를 제대로 풍자하기도 하고 깨알같은 패러디도 많아 이 쪽이 꽤 재밌다. '동사 학교' 같은 경우는 웹페이지에서 무료로도 플레이해볼 수 있다고 하니, 꼭 게임을 살 것이 아니라도 이 쪽은 한 번 플레이해보길 추천.

동사 9개를 적절한 상황에 활용해야 하는 복고풍의 게임플레이를 자랑한다. 단축키도 안 먹혀서 되게 옛스럽고 불편할 것 같은데, 게임이 상당히 짧기도 하고 생각보다 난해한 상황은 잘 없어서 스토리만 잘 따라가면 막힐 일은 거의 없을 것이다. 다만 대사 스킵 기능을 제대로 안 넣은 게 좀 문제가 된다. 

결국은 도전과제 100%용 게임. 가격이 저렴하고 하니 한글화가 되준다면 한 번 해볼만은 한 게임이다.

38622019.review:
Yorkshire Gubbins is a point-and-click adventure game clearly inspired by games made during the heyday of the genre in the mid-90s. Thankfully, the game eschews referential meta jokes about that era of gaming and instead uses the conventions and tropes of the genre to deliver a fun, charming (but short) experience. Retro-inspired games can often feel exploitative of nostalgia, but this is a straight revival and that appealed to me as a fan of the genre.

The game is really nice to look at. The "big pixel" art style used for the character sprites is reminiscent of the scaling artefacts seen in ScummVM or Sierra games, but remains expressive throughout. The sprites' idle animations and fancy shader effects help the world look alive and engaging.

Speaking of, this is a fully voiced game and the voice acting really adds a layer of cohesion to the game. It's possibly the single strongest element in YG. It's really good and a pleasure to listen to.

Story-wise, the game's episodes work well as self-contained units of silliness. There's the expected item retrieval quests and character distraction subplots, but there is no overarching plot or dramatic tension. This makes sense considering the game's two episodes and tutorial can be completed in one sitting but it might frustrate some players.

One aspect of Yorskhire Gubbins that feels limiting is the fact that all objects and characters are present on the same plane of depth. On the one hand, it means there's no pixel-hunting, but on the other it makes the world look flat and takes away from the sense of exploration. The game works around that limitation to deliver a fun experience, but it might become a problem for longer and more ambitious future episodes.

But really, the reason I'm writing this review is the setting. I didn't have the grace and foresight to be born an Englishman and, for that reason, I have no great familiarity with either Yorkshire itself or how it's depicted in British media.
I was a bit apprehensive that the game would rely heavily on regional stereotypes and tropes to get its laughs and that these would woosh over my head.

Having played the game, I'm very pleased to report that this isn't the case. Yorkshire is to the game what the fantasy genre and sci-fi are to Simon the Sorcerer and the Space Quest games, respectively. It's the substrate on which the game's humour grows - but it's not itself the joke.

[b]Pros[/b]
[*] Stellar voice acting
[*] Pure 90s-style point-and-click adventure silliness
[*] Humour is situational, not referential
[*] Unique English regional setting, yet remains accessible to the rest of us
[*] Looks good, runs well
[*] Fun achievements

[b]Cons[/b]
[*] Music is unobtrusive but meh

[b]Protip[/b]
Play the [i]Holy Molluscamony[/i] bonus episode before [i]Humble Pie[/i].

38601159.review: 'ave a pint at 'ome instead of at t' pub and spend t' money you save on this crackin game. Yorkshire approved™

38486974.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Yorkshire Gubbins is the debut Steam title from developers Stairfall Institute, published by Green Mesa Ltd.

In Yorkshire Gubbins -- what there is of it so far, anyway -- you control Steggy, a lass from Yorkshire with a penchant for droll comments and an affinity for pie making. In the introductory episode a robot introduces both you and Steggy to the workings of the game's interface in Verb School, and at the bargain price of only 20p, too!

The game proper begins after that, with the episode called Humble Pie. This sees Steggy foiled in the last stages of preparing her entry for the Yorkshire Pie Competition when she finds a serious problem with a key pie ingredient: her Special Meat is in fact only normal meat in a Special Meat wrapper.

Pixelated point-and-click hilarity ensues as you guide Steggy through various encounters and simple inventory puzzles in search of some real Special Meat, and a chance at pie greatness.

[h1]Presentation[/h1]
The graphics in Yorkshire Gubbins are chunky pixel graphics. They're really chunky: too chunky to really enjoy in full-screen at HD resolutions, and much more chunky even than something like Lucasarts' The Secret of Monkey Island (the original), from the 1990s.

The game only includes a small number of characters and locations. Locations are somewhat bland -- but then again, the game is set in a town in Yorkshire! -- but the characters have all been infused with some personality. Each character has an idle animation, and in-game objects are drawn well enough to at least be recognisable.

The interface is extremely simple and SCUMM-like: a series of nine verbs, each of which can be applied to selectable objects on the screen. The cursor is a set of large white crosshairs and interactive objects or characters are indicated by partially formed sentences at the bottom of the screen, using the currently selected verb.

The game has minimal music, but what is included fits the game and setting perfectly and is well produced: simple ditties using only a couple of instruments. I don't recall any sound effects, but there may have been some.

The big appeal to the game's audio is the fully voiced dialogue, mostly consisting of Yorkshire accents. (I admit, I'm not familiar enough with Yorkshire accents to know if these are real, but they sound pretty convincing to me.) Every line of text in the game is spoken and the voices mostly sound professional and work extremely well. I did hear a few places where it sounded a little muddy, and a couple of voices that didn't sound quite as convincing as the rest, but overall it was well done.

Subtitles are optional. I kept them turned on and noticed a few places where the spoken text was different to the written words, which I always find a bit jarring. The grammar was mostly excellent; I only noticed a couple of errors across all three current episodes.

There are limited options: three volume levels each for music and sound, fullscreen / windowed mode toggle for graphics, and a single special effect filter: "Steggyvision', which appears to be a sort of bright blur lighting effect for characters and interface elements. I can't imagine any modern PCs experiencing performance issues with the game.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Yorkshire Gubbins is a traditional point-and-click adventure game. The game takes place in the top three quarters of the screen, with the bottom quarter being reserved for the simple interface: nine verbs, selectable by word, and a small inventory area. As with any point-and-click adventure, your goal is to find your way to the end of the story by solving verb- and inventory- based puzzles. The gameplay offers nothing revolutionary; indeed, it is obviously heavily influenced by the classics of the genre, such as the SCUMM-based Lucasarts games of the 1990s, and it does a good job.

The core of every good point-and-click adventure is its puzzles, and Yorkshire Gubbins follows the rulebook here, too. There's nothing outlandishly difficult and, so far at least, you shouldn't need to resort to a walkthrough. I did find one puzzle that was a bit fiddly and required a bit of the old "use everything on everything in the scene" tactic; though I knew what I wanted to do I just couldn't work out how the game wanted me to do it.

The game is divided into episodes. Currently there's a short tutorial of about 10-15 minutes' length, a single episode of somewhere between 60-90 minutes, and a 'bonus' prequel episode with a play time somewhere between the other two. Even though the game is not marked as Early Access, the developers are being generous and planning to offer a few more episodes free to owners of the game over the next year. So while the game as it is now only provides about two hours of play, you can expect more over the coming months.

The script is well written and the game's main drawcard is its humour, which I found entertaining; it didn't fall flat like many other comedy games and it even made me laugh out loud a few times.

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
Pros:
+ Sense of humour
+ Great accents
+ Steam Achievements

Cons:
- Pixel graphics are a bit too low resolution for modern displays
- Variable voice acting quality
- Very short (so far; more is coming)

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
Yorkshire Gubbins is a very welcome addition to the point-and-click adventure genre, with comedy that's light-hearted and fun. At the moment there's not much here, but what there is is well written and funny. The promise of up to another four long episodes over the next year adds to the appeal. Yorkshire Gubbins made me laugh out loud more than once, which is quite rare in this age of memes and in-your-face slapstick.

If you like point-and-click adventure games and you appreciate good humour, then pick it up and take a look.

Humans love buttons!

[h1]Save[/h1]

[code]For more game reviews, visit [url=http://saveorquit.com/]Save or Quit[/url].[/code]

Yorkshire Gubbins is a point and click comedy adventure game set in a Yorkshire town, with stone and brick buildings, ginnels and... slug monsters. Whilst the slug monster plotline is a metaphor for the state of current day politics, the gameplay is so entertaining and rewarding, one can overlook this due to laughing so much.
The voice acting is good, the developers sourced local talent, and the story is engaging. I look forward to future episodes. 
I played this on a Linux (Ubuntu 16.04) machine and it had very good performance, no problems at all. Recommended.

36173130.review:
This actually happened last week. All of it. In Golcar. Weirdly prescient of you, really.

ANYWAY.

Despite making me put actual brain power into working out Spork Jogger and deciding the world may never forgive you, this is a pretty cool clickypointy adventure game. Exactly the sort of thing to while away the time on a rainy afternoon with. [b]*[/b] The puzzles are maybe a tad easy for some, but then again I've know people basically claim to have finished Riven in 9 minutes without any hints because [i]that[/i] was too easy. Those people are liars and shall go to the Bad Place when they die, so take any comments about difficulty with a pinch of salt. Myself, I thought it was a nice game to chill with.

So yeah. If you're a fan of adventures, buy it.

[b]* - [/b] [i]Note that rainy afternoon is not mandatory, but considered necessary for the Full Yorkshire Experience. As, possibly, is being "gritty", but as nobody's ever managed to explain precisely what that means to me I'm a bit hesitant to recommend it.

36146561.review:
Disclaimer: I know the dev

I love point and click games, and thoroughly enjoyed Holy Molluscamony when it was released after Adventure Jam. Naturally I was excited when I heard it was being expanded into a set of short adventures in the same universe!

I started with the verb school. It feels like a great intoduction to point and click games, but also is a fantastic introduction to the look and feel of the game, as well as the humor.

I then moved on to playing the updated version of Holy Molluscamony. 5 months after originally playing it, I can say I enjoyed it just as much. The voices have been updated too, which is a nice touch.

I then moved on to Humble Pie. Solid humor, not too difficult, but fabulously executed. Really enjoyed playing it!

Throughout the games, it's a chunky pixel art style (that I love) that still gets across what the items are. The dialog is well written and is funny, with great references to other things in nerd culture as well as being self referential.

I would 100% recommend this, especially at the asking price. It's well worth it.

36047009.review: When even the tutorial chapter for a point and click adventure gives you the chuckles you know you are onto a good thing. The contrast between the normal and outlandish is always fertile ground and likewise in going from handling your mum and an episode of 'Yorkshire's Fattest Dogs' to dealing with Slug Clones and escaped robots in it's first episode Yorkshire Gubbins plants the seeds of a great series. Looking forward to episode two!

36045230.review:
I rarely write reviews. when I do it's normally for a small indie game that feels as though the heart and soul of the creator has been poured into it. This is such a game. Made in the vain of classic SCUMM engine games of my youth, [b]Yorkshire Gubbins[/b] leads you on an adventure, of Robots, Aliens and...Pies!
It's packed with lovely humourous touches, with superb voice acting and a delightful retro graphic style. The puzzles are taxing, wihtout being overly obtuse, something which some point and click games fail to get right ([i]"oh so I had to combine the melon with a copy of Time magazine and give it to the one armed man..."[/i]).
[b]Yorkshire Gubbins[/b] cost's about the same as a pint in a trendy London wine bar, but is way more enjoyable. Pick it up you won't regret it.

35954990.review:
Installed on Linux. My setup is fairly low end:

CPU   Q8200  @ 2.33GHz
550Ti graphics
8 GB ram
Xubuntu Linux 17.04 (64 bit)

The game used all cores and used a total of 25% overall CPU, going up a little bit higher when the screen was scrolling. There was no judder, or for that matter, any technical issues while playing through the game.

The game itself is a humorous adventure game with retro-style graphics and classic point and click gameplay. While short, the game was highly enjoyable and the humour genuinely funny. The voice acting and music were very good too. Highly recommended to point and click aficionados. Looking forward to further chapters.

35947513.review:
It's been a while since I ventured into the world of pointing, clicking and adventuring all in one game. I miss a decent pointy clicky thing to be honest so I loaded up t'online game shop and bought this. I can honestly say on the life of my whippet* this is the pointiest and clickiest game I've played all year.

The Yorkshire setting may terrify you if you are a British southerner or from 'not the UK' but it's ok. The game is written with simplified Yorkshire voiceovers and if you struggle with that there are subtitles. As a southerner myself I found this game highly accessible and I feel I learned much about the rich Yorkshire culture, particularly their plight against other-worldly creatures and a liking for pie.

The game is beautifully drawn and *fully pixelated* such that if you squint and engage your imagination, you start to experience what the real Yorkshire looks like. Kinda like the real point and click adventures from the 80s and 90s. Do not squint for long as you may feel like you have left your life behind and now run a pub in the peak district.

I found the episodes to date amusing if a little short, but if you're after a quick diversion from life and fancy a visit to deepest, muddiest Yorkshire where the beer costs 20p, then this game may be to your liking, especially as it is cheaper than a bus ticket to Burnley.

*DISCLAIMER: I don't actually have a whippet

35942785.review:
A solid, funny, little point and click adventure game.

The sense of humour is right up my alley (or ginnel, as the case may be), and it's definitely worth the price of admission.

While Yorkshire Gubbins certainly isn't as, ah, reflective on the morality of genre norms as Undertale (you do some reasonably terrible things, in traditional adventure game fashion), the humour is broadly similar if you were a fan of that. It's a bit more British though.

It also isn't too hard, and certainly if you're someone who's offended at the notion of games not lasting for 100 hours this might not necessarily be for you, but for less than the price of a cinema ticket it's definitely worth it for what's in the game right now, and I can't see that changing when subsequent episodes come out (even if the price goes up a bit*).

* It'll actually also probably still be less than a cinema ticket. Cinema tickets are *really* expensive, having just looked up what cinemas actually charge nowadays. The non-sale price (£4 as of writing) of Yorkshire Gubbins could double and still be cheaper than buying a ticket from Odeon (£9.75 for an adult, not including booking fee if you're getting it online, also as of writing). In Standard seating. And I'd bet you still have to watch adverts... But yeah, good value, good game, buy it, *thumbs up emoji*.

35932796.review: I quite liked the first episode.

35923413.review: Great fun, can't wait for the next instalment.

35897861.review: Charming, funny, and highly polished little gem. Recommended to any fan of point and click adventures! Great voice acting, and the funniest credits I've seen!

35890291.review:
As a Yorkshireman born and bred, I can confirm to Lancastrians and other foreigners that Yorkshire Gubbins is indeed an accurate Yorkshire Simulator, taking in our green and pleasant land with parks, terrace houses, ginnels, and of course Yorkshire's famous robotics industry.

This important piece of media also brings to the front the plight of our slugkin population, so often overlooked owing to their tendency to clone people and/or the masses of slime they exude. Sticky, gluey slime.

In all seriousness, though: Yorkshire Gubbins is a fantastic romp for any fan of classic comedy-driven point 'n' click adventures, and thanks to the Verb School tutorial - entirely optional, but definitely recommended even if you know what you're doing - can act as a great introduction to the genre. The graphics are vintage with a modern twist thanks to the SteggyVision filter, and you can even fluidly resize the window - great for sneaking in a quick bit of Yorkshire at work, but you didn't hear that from me.

While it's admittedly a short adventure, it's a fun one - and with the promise of more to come in the future I'm confident my sub-£5 investment will prove wise.

Huzzah for Yorkshire| Huzzah for Slugkin| Huzzah for Yorkshire Gubbins!

I just want to make sure people know exactly what they're getting right now: There's 1 hour long episode Humble Pie (plus the shorter Verb School and Holy Molluscamony) to play now, with 4 more episodes planned which people will get automatically for no extra charge over the next 8-9 months. :)

35836143.review:
This game is an extremely witty love letter to my home county, and all its mad denizens, and I love it deeply.
Puzzling your way through the tasks is entertaining enough, but what you'll come back for is the cast of characters, the surreal humour, and the clean, safe and normal Yorkshire Robots.
Very much looking forward to the next installment :)

35828159.review:
A wonderful point'n'click game with a Yorkshire Twist. The games are short but wonderfully paced, and chock-full of humour.

In a world with open world sandboxes, microtransactions and a nationwide ban on salt, this is the perfect antidote... Well, mostly. 2 outta 3 ain't bad, is it?

35819484.review: I was hyped for this as soon as I saw the first trailer and it did not disappoint. A fun game with a great sense of humour and the very soul of Yorkshire at its foundation, not to mention the most relatable protagonist I've ever played.

35817300.review:
2017, what a year for old school adventure games!

First Thimbleweed Park, then Darkside Detective and now Yorkshire Gubbins!

The game is actually fun to play - amazing voice acting and wicked sense of humour together with a great price point make this an insta buy for me (and probably lots of my friends for Christmas). 

If you like Monkey Island and British humour just pay those 4 quid and take this home.

35814587.review:
Disclaimer: I know the dev personally.

This is a genuinely funny, and slightly surreal, point-and-click adventure with some excellent voice acting and a distinctive art style: particularly if you are a resident of or fan of God's County.

It's pretty short at the moment but for one episode and a tutorial (a tutorial! For a point-and-click!) that both contain moments of laugh out loud laughter, it's definitely worth the entry fee requested.

35814400.review:
If you love classic point-and-click adventures with puzzles that aren't too hard, this game is for you. If you love Yorkshire based humour, even better. The usual rules apply, look at everything, talk to everyone and you'll finish the game in just over an hour or so, more if you want to find all achievements. The user interface from Holy Molluscamony (the first game of the series published independently and included as prequel in this game) has been improved and you can right-click for default actions like going through doors. You don't need to play the tutorial to learn how it works but it's worth playing for the wonderful voice acting and the somewhat left-field humour. 
It leaves you wanting more but the good news is that more is to come in the next episode in the hopefully not too far future.

35813417.review:
Reet good adventure game set in my home county. Played for just under an hour and it seems like there's still a fair bit to do - I'm guessing it'll be a couple of hours in total, which is great for the price. Funny and charming, and shows an obvious love for the classic Lucasarts game, while still very much being its own thing.

If tha likes classic adventures, get tha sen a copy.

35812684.review: Fantastic funny and fun game. Loving playing this.

35808811.review:
A great point and click adventure game with a bunch of English wit to it -- great voice acting, great writing, and great artwork. Definitely a good play if you enjoy this sort of game -- even if you don't, it's pretty funny!

The tutorial isn't needed if you've ever played something like Maniac Mansion or Monkey Island, but I recommend doing it anyway; there's a few laughs to be had. Total play time of the tutorial, episode 1, and the bonus episode was just under 2 hours. 

Catch my playthrough on YouTube:

https://youtu.be/FnedEFG3Z2E

35806907.review:
[h1]Proper Champion & Reet Gradeley[/H1]
Excellent point & click adventure game from God's Own Country. If you're new to point & clicks, the tutorial is excellent, if you're not, it's still excellent because it, like the rest of the game, is hilarious.

13/10 Bathtubs down hills

35806654.review: Now then - if tha lahks t'Yorksher accent, 'appen tha might try this reet grand title, all aboot a pie competition or summat. Ah've not finished but so far ah'm gobsmacked by the EGA graphics, champion soundblaster din and authentic dialect. Also good for incomers like missen. Not much brass neither.

35806520.review:
I've been playing for about an hour and it's a laugh a minute. The narrative of the story is so daft and funny, core British comedy but I'm sure it translates well to non British folk :)

I now know what's in the box!

35806498.review:
What can I say?

Well, definitely worth playing the bundled prequel, [i]Holy Molluscamony[/i], first. Unless you live in Yorkshire (or Westminster) and thus have a prior acquaintance with ginormous encroaching gastropods.

As an inhabitant of [b]REDACTED[/b] I really must take issue with the notion that the best pies are from Yorkshire, but hey, this is intended to be a twisted, tangential look at the North of England, so we'll let that slide, like many of the characters will after a little beer.

Everything else is naturally, 100% accurate. As an Southern outsider and a keen observer of the Northern Wastes of Britain, all I can say is, you can never go back. Largely because of the ridiculous house prices.

For those of you yet to experience the joys of The North, I can heartily recommend this as the warning you need to stay away. For those of us trapped here, sit back and enjoy a world where the slug monsters aren't in Westminster. Yet.

Wry, funny, and like houses in the North, a bargain to get 5 at the price you'd usually get one for.

35806061.review: This game is absolutely hilarious. Great stuff!

35805384.review:
Ran perfectly, out of the box. Lovely design concept, well executed, but be sure to do the tutorial if you're not used to 8-bit games (I was used to 'em half a lifetime ago, but everything goes away eventually). Don't bother with fullscreen as it just isn't designed to look its best at large size.


Once you've done the tutorial the gameplay is a cinch, but be prepared for a hefty cultural learning curve ...

35805123.review: Thoroughly enjoyed this lovely and hilarious game. Story is bizarre, but pretty great. Make sure you play the tutorial, it is actually really fun. This game also proves that more voice overs should be done by people with Yorkshire accents.

35804908.review:
A fantastic point and click adventure with enough humour to blow your freakin socks off

It will remind you of such classics as Monkey Island and Beneath a Steel Sky whilst keeping you grounded with good ol Yorkshire chat

Do yourself a favour don't order that double mocha coffee crap, spend the money on this then poor yourself a cup of Yorkshire tea and be entertained

35804674.review: Considered uninstalling after my immersion was broken ("what's with [strike]the[/strike] box?"). Stuck with it and found a decent, if short point and click game, even if I did have to work 27 hours a day, 9 days a week in't pit just to afford it.

35803952.review:
As a fan of the old Monkey Island games, I thought I'd pick this one up as it looked like it had a pretty similar style to it.

I wasn't disappointed - clearly a lot of work has gone into Yorkshire Gubbins.

It's not [i]quite[/i] like Monkey Island as the game is played completely in 2D, but it's got all the charm and atmosphere which gives that nostaligia itch a damn good scratch.

Possibly one of the best, most noticable elements of the game is the great music. Whilst it's not the sort of stuff you'd hum along to, it's suitably atmospheric and has a really warm and fuzzy feel to it.

The sound overall is great, with all the dialog performed well with genuine Yorkshire or Southerner accents. 

The writing is really superb and genuinely funny, although perhaps it would be obvious that a game called "Yorkshire Gubbins"  would have somewhat of a Northern bias - making southerners out to be a bit pompous. They aren't pompous. They're hipsters with beards and tattoos. Duh.

Overall, the game is nice, fun, friendly and casual. Give it a go.

35801875.review:
Probably the first time I've enjoyed a tutorial. 

Very funny game, enjoyed it a lot. The judge is a tosspot

35801545.review:
Cool Game. Funny and weird. And buying it now when you get all the rest of the episodes after this for no additional cost is a darn good deal. 

Also it starts with a Y, so it'll probably be easy to find at the bottom of your Steam library. Unless you have lots of games starting with Z.

35801410.review: Hilarious and 100% accurate repsentation of daily life in Yorkshire, delivered in Point + Click form.

35799611.review:
I played through the tutorial of this and was giggling a lot.

Then I got into the real game and kept having to stop because I was laughing so much.

I don't know how replayable it will be once you know all the jokes, but at this price, it's fine as a complete throwaway one-shot.

Also, it's proper funny.

35799050.review:
A fantastic, funny point and click adventure, with a brilliant tutorial to get you going if you've never played one before.

Definitely worth picking up for a few quid, especially with the promise of more episodes to come!
